thread.title: Teen slammed to the ground at pool party files $5 million lawsuit
thread.title_full: Teen slammed to the ground at pool party files $5 million lawsuit

author: ELIZABETH ELIZALDE
title: Teen slammed to the ground at pool party files $5 million lawsuit
text:
Teen slammed to the ground at pool party files $5 million lawsuit against Texas cop, city Teen slammed to the ground at pool party files $5 million lawsuit NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, January 3, 2017, 9:41 PM 
The teenage girl who was seen slammed to the ground by a Texas police officer on video during a 2015 summer pool party has filed a $5 million federal lawsuit against the cop, the city and the police department. 
Dajerria Becton is seeking $5 million in damages after McKinney police officer Eric Casebolt pinned down the bikini-clad 15-year-old at a pool party at the upscale Craig Ranch community on June 5, 2015. 
Those damages include “mental anguish, loss of quality of life as well as attorney fees,” according to a lawsuit obtained by the Dallas Morning News. Dajerria Becton has filed a $5 million federal lawsuit against the cop, the city, and the police department. (fox4news) 
“The City of McKinney denies the claims alleged against it and the McKinney Police Department,” city officials said in a statement to the newspaper. McKinney police officer Eric Casebolt has Dajerria Becton pinned on the ground. (BRANDON BROOKS VIA YOUTUBE) 
Police said they were called to the Craig Ranch North Community Pool because neighbors reported fights among the teens. 
Becton said she was invited to the party and was trying to get away from the rowdy scene when Casebolt approached her. Demonstrators gathered near the Craig Ranch Pool for a protest three days after the June 5, 2015 incident. (Ron Jenkins/AP) 
The officer can be seen in a cell phone video, taken by an eyewitness, grabbing the teen by the hair and pushing her onto the grass. Lying facedown on her stomach, Casebolt appeared to rest his knees on the teen's back to restrain her. 
Texas teacher loses job for rant about McKinney pool party 
Casebolt resigned from the department after the chief called his actions “out of control.” A grand jury decided not to indict Casebolt last June after reviewing evidence from a Texas Rangers investigation. Adrian Martin, 18, in dark blue shirt and tan shorts, tried to help a teenage girl who was being subdued by Eric Casebolt during a McKinney, Texas, pool party. (Deezil Greezil via YouTube) 
Becton said in court that Casebolt handcuffed her even though she followed his commands. The suit states the teen cried from the pain she endured as she repeatedly called for her mother during the incident. 
Casebolt’s attorneys have earlier said that the cop was suicidal at one point and that he wasn’t specifically targeting minorities. Tags:
